DOC.HEAD: SEC Withdraws Appeal in 1983 Case
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission has withdrawn an appeal to a federal judge's dismissal of its 6{-year-old civil case against Blinder, Robinson & Co. Inc., officials said Monday. Tom Carter, SEC regional counsel, said the withdrawal was filed Dec. 11 in the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. He declined to comment on the reason, but said it had nothing to do with a separate disciplinary inquiry the SEC has undertaken into the activities of Blinder, Robinson, a leading penny stock brokerage. Penny stocks are inexpensive shares of startup companies ranging from biotechnology research labs to energy and mining concerns. The stocks usually are traded over-the-counter and have been targeted by federal authorities as a frequent breeding ground for fraud. The SEC filed the civil case in April 1983, contending Blinder, Robinson had failed to keep correct books and records and violated customer protection regulations. In April, U.S. District Judge Lewis T. Babcock dismissed the case after determining the SEC failed to comply with a court order and had not acted in good faith. The judge also said the SEC could not use documents or testimony obtained in the 1983 case in court against Blinder, Robinson. Babcock said his ruling was justified by ``the SEC's egregious conduct in this case.'' On Dec. 12, Babcock ordered the SEC to pay Blinder, Robinson $58,575 in attorney's fees, Carter said. In a news release issued Monday, Blinder, Robinson executives said they are pleased ``that justice has been served by the award of attorney fees and costs to defendants.'' Carter said the SEC is considering a possible appeal to the specific amount of the fees.
